I use this phone in T mobile so far I have great experience. Build quality is extremely good for this price. Looks like $400 phone. Build quality is no less than Galaxy Note 4. The case come with is also premium quality. But they cut some corner to keep the cost low. The stock wall charger comes with it is only 1A charger. I use a 2A charger with 1 feet usb cable to fix the charging time in case i need to charge fast. But slow charging is good for the Li Ion battery life. So no complain there. I do not play game. But for all apps I am using have no issue with the speed of this phone. I thinks they have made a perfect balance between cost and performance in this phone.

Another place they cut the cost is the speaker amplifier. Speaker volume is not that great. I use speaker a lot for watching sling TV, Netfix and other streaming on the phone. There is a software fix available for boosting the speaker volume. Download the app called "Speaker Boost" from play store and boost the volume by 20%. Make sure you set a clamp at 20% otherwise it will destroy your speaker. above 20% i notice that speaker started making noise.

Since they are using Media Tek chip set, I was worried about the modem performance on tmobile but it seems to be working much better than qualcomm 801 chipset. At home I used to have 2 bar and 4G only with qualcomm chip set. Now with this phone I am getting 3 bar and 4G LTE at home and speedtest.net app showing about 40 mbps download which is far beyond of my expectation. I used to get less than 10 mbps with qualcomm 801.

Both front and back camera are great in this phone. If you use the case you can still take the picture without opening the case by drawing C and use volume up or down key to take picture with the back camera. I like that very much to take quick shot. The video mode also have pause button that I appreciate very much and a must have option for me.

Couple of issue I still couldn't solve. I didn't find any repeat notification option in the phone setting for missed called or text. I like to have a sound notification for any missed call or text every 2 min. Repeat notification apps from google play store also not working for this phone. If anyone able to get this working please comment. I also like to have root access to install greenify app to improve battery life but do not know how to root this phone. Please comment if you know.

I will update the review if I find any issue later.

Update 12/31/2015: I was able to root the device following the instruction in this thread "forum.xda-developers.com/showpost.php?p=64508454&postcount=41". Just install "Minimal ADB and Fastboot" and exactly follow the instruction took me about 20 min to root.

This is quite a fantastic phone for the price. $150 is a great deal for the hardware you get, and if you bought it during the first couple days of promotion for $99 like I did, then it's very good value. Let me cover the basics:

SCREEN - Full HD, 1080p screen. There's better screens out there, and you DON'T need them. 1080p at this size looks perfect, no pixels discernible. Having any more resolution is only good for a) marketing or b) draining your battery. Colors are nice, contrast is good, brightness is great - that said, the auto-brightness, when enabled, tends to err a bit on the darker side.

INTERNALS - This is not your usual Qualcomm Snapdragon, but the new contender Mediatek. I'll spare you the technical details: it's an 8-core CPU based on 8 ARM Cortex A-53 processors. They are not the fastest in the market, but they don't need to be. Paired with its 2GB of RAM, this phone is snappy. No app really takes "long" to load, everything (FB, Skype, Messenger, SMS, Chrome, Fibit, etc) loads in well under a second, with the occasional hiccup. There's only one negative to not having a Qualcomm CPU - there's no quickcharge here, so it does take longer (2h) to fully charge, instead of less than 1h on the newer Qualcomm processors. As long as you have enough time to charge it in the morning, or you charge it overnight, though, this is not a problem.

BATTERY - Used to be good from the beginning, then after the late January update it got better. Usually I'll finish the day with about %40-50 battery left and I charge it in the morning, never really getting it back to %100 but to %80-90 or so. A normal day of semi-heavy use (taking pictures, posting pictures, FB, twitter, instagram, lots of email, some chrome browsing, lots of podcast playing) consumes about half the capacity. Pretty great for the price compared to my previous Moto E LTE 2nd gen.

BODY - Very well built with metal, faux leather in the back and a very slim build. Compared to other $100 devices, this thing rocks. Compared to the Moto G 3rd gen, this is much better built, but lacks the water resistance. Feels nice in the hand and is very light. If your hands are on the smaller side like mine, though, holding with one hand isn't terribly comfortable, but that's a problem with any phone at this size.

CAMERA - 13mp on the back, 5mp on the front. I'm mostly impressed with the front camera: I've been so used to having absolutely awful cameras in the front, that this Blu taking quite decent selfies surprised me. The back camera is good, but nothing spectacular, certainly not on the level of an iPhone or a Galaxy S - but then again, this phone costs about %25 what the flagships cost. So, for the price it's being sold at, the camera is excellent. I challenge you to find a better one at this price range.
SOFTWARE - 5.1 Lollipop right off the bat, already updated in late January. We're supposedly getting 6.0 marshmallow by end of first quarter, so I'll be looking forward to that. I read in many forums that other users were skeptical about this, but so far Blu seems on top of their game. Apparently keeping their phones updated is a new priority for them and they're starting with the Life One X. We'll see if they hold to their promise (after Motorola betrayed my confidence by not updating my Moto E LTE 2nd Gen, I'm a bit cynical... but then again, this Blu is so much more device for the same money, so if it weren't updated, I wouldn't care so much because the phone is so nice to use). There are a couple quirks, like the fact that the phone ringtone refuses to change. For some reason, my podcast app (Pocket Casts) which worked fine on the Moto, can no longer remember where I paused the podcast, so I have to manually bring it back to where I was. I think this has to do with driver issues, so hopefully it'll be fixed in the 6.0 update, but again, even if it's not, these are minor inconveniences.

VERDICT - Great phone for little money. I keep hearing 2016 is the year of the rise of the cheap mid-range, where we'll get excellent devices like this for around $99-150. So far, this Blu is the only one I've seen make that a reality. You get good hardware, snappy performance, (hopefully) updated software to 6.0, beautiful screen, decent camera and all for a cheap price. I used to be a Windows Phone user until I jumped back into Android with the Moto E LTE 2nd Gen, and the Lumias give you so much LESS hardware for the money this Blu costs. Even Motorola, the value king lately, gives you way less for this price. Blu has a home-run with this Life One X.

Highly recommended.

UPDATE 5/7/2016: While he phone still works great, it's been nearly 2 months since the date BLU assured users that we'd get Marshmallow (Android 6.0). For that reason alone I'm dropping my review from 5 to 2 stars: false advertising is unacceptable and having based my purchase on the timely upgrade promise, I feel like I have been lied to.

No thing to say

Purchased this phone for my Mom for Christmas as a replacement to her Moto X (1st Gen). HIGHLY impressed with the speed, responsiveness, and build quality of this phone for the price! Takes great pictures and has already survived a few drops on the floor! Mom loved the front facing camera with the selfie flash, and I was quite impressed with the quality of the resulting selfie as well. I HIGHLY recommend this phone for anyone that needs a quality replacement phone for an aging or broken device. This phone easily equals or outperforms a Samsung Galaxy S4. BLU will likely be my go-to budget brand for the foreseeable future. Well done BLU! Keep up the good work!

I've been using the phone for about a month now and I use it extensively, gaming, video streaming, you name it I did it.

So here are the pros and cons I have found:

PROS:
-Fast
-Light
-Looks and feels great
-Screen is very responsive and doesn't show fingerprints easily
-Good camera, takes good close ups, not the best at night, but it's not bad nonetheless
-Good Battery Life, for it being an 8 core processor, it gets good life, not the best but will last all day into the night
-Charges FAST, this phone charges amazingly fast with the stock wall adapter, Takes about 30 minutes to charge from 60-70% after being used all day.
-Speaker is loud, not the clearest but works great as an alarm in the morning

CONS:
-When gaming or streaming videos, you eat the battery like nobody's business
-Screen is a battery eater as well
-Stock android can have compatability issues, such as with my Sony bluetooth car stereo, it doesn't buffer music properly for the radio works fine with all bluetooth headphones I have tested it with
-You MUST disable a LOT of stock google apps to increase battery life! (READ BELOW! LOTS OF PEOPLE HAVE THIS PROBLEM!)
-Wifi connectivity isn't the best, still good for the price though, mobile data is very speedy though

So In many reviews I have seen of this phone, at idle, it eats a lot of the battery. I had this problem in the first 3 days of having it, and I decided to figure out what "System" really was. Turns out, stock google apps like Books and Newsstand eat a lot of processing even when idle. I disabled most of google's stock apps like this due to me never going to use them. After I did this, I noticed a significant increase in battery life, and it's still doing fine to this day.

All in all, I love this phone, I hate iPhones and expensive android phones, this meets and exceeds my needs yet is still powerfull when I need it to be. I recommend it to everyone I see. If you have a teenager who's looking for a good looking and fast phone that he can game with, get this phone and get a gel case for it, I got one for 6$ shipped and it does a great job protecting the phone. The phone also comes with Gorilla Glass 3 installed, so the screen is well protected from breaks, however it comes with a screen protector just in case.

This phone comes with some earbuds that are also very decent, the mic was clear in calls, and the earbuds sounded good for normal music use. Mind you, they're nothing special, but they pack a punch on the low end of the frequency response, so that's a plus.

When it's all said and done, this phone is worth every cent, it has good cameras for selfies and for regular daytime pictures, also close ups. Fast and light, with a good looking and responsive screen. Lightweight with a good battery life and solid feel, this phone really gives the vibe of a much more expensive phone.

To start off i am not a paid reviewer, this my own review of the product. The features that are offered on this phone cannot be beat by anyone currently, i paid $99 for this phone when they were running the 3 day promotion. $99 for a almost pure android phone, WITH LTE, expendable storage, and a GOOD camera, that's all packed in a aluminum frame is under heard of. It runs fast and doesn't lag, although I don't game on it. The only reason I give it three stars is because of the slow charging. The battery also doesn't last me a whole day, as some users claim. I am a power user, and I do use it as a hot spot a lot, so while I can understand the battery holds pretty good (and it got better after I the OTA update), the slow charging is reeaaally a drag.

Then there is also the included screen protector, which for some reason, doesn't cover the whole screen. If you are including a screen protector OEM style, it should fit the whole screen. I'm also not a fan of the included case, I'd rather have a skin or sleeve style rubber/tpu cover and not have to deal with flipping the cover open every time I want to use the phone.

Also, for some reason, even though it has band 12 coverage for T-Mobile, my girlfriends Moto E gets better data signal in the same house and also works better as a hot spot.

If it wasn't for these nuisances it would be the perfect phone.

I won't say, "For the price this phone is great". Simply, this is a great phone. The price is just a bonus. I hope I can find a case for it in the future.

I generally don't leave reviews but felt I should for this product.

I've only had it for about three days, but I can generally get a good feel for a smartphone in that period of time. For a frame of reference, I have owned many smartphones on the iOS, Android, and Windows platforms. My most current of each is an iPhone 6, an ASUS ZenFone 2, and a Lumia 640.

Comparing it to the iPhone 6, from a hardware perspective this phone is quite comparable, NFC and fingerprint reader aside. Compared to the ZenFone 2, this feels like a more premium device and is more responsive, although again it lacks NFC.

OVERALL:
While there are some minor drawbacks, this is a great device for the money. It feels premium, the screen is nice and responsive, the skin on the OS is minimal and the features they've added are useful. For an everyday device, this certainly fits the bill.

PROS:
*Cost -- I was able to get this during the presale, and while it took a while to ship, the value for the price is outstanding
*Reception -- I am on T-Mobile in NYC and with the additional 12 band I get much better reception indoors and on the subway. Calls are clear on both ends.
*OS -- I am a fan of the Nexus devices and Motorola's approach to Android. BLU has taken the Motorola approach and I appreciate the minimal additions they've made.

CONS:
*Battery -- As many others have pointed out, the battery is slow to recharge regardless of what charger I use. However, the battery life is very good. I am a heavy user and am able to make it through most of the day on a single charge. To be safe, though, I do charge it during the day.
*Bluetooth -- As someone else mentioned, the Bluetooth transmitter on the device is a little on the weak side. Both on the street and in my house, I have experienced a lot of interference using both headphones and speakers. As a nice aside, it does work with Amazon's three-button headphones that were sold with the Fire Phone.
*Camera -- shutter is slower than I'm used to, but the photo quality is good and the camera app is nicely minimal and a step-up from the Motorola Camera app.
*No NFC -- I love using mobile payment and am unable to use on this device (alas).

First of all, a reminder to all who already purchased this phone and gave bad reviews:  THIS IS A $150 PHONE!

Disclaimer:  I've owned range of high-end phones, and currently have Blackberry Priv and LG V10 - both being "High End" phones.  So I *KNOW* my apples, and my oranges!

You wouldn't compare KIA to BMW, so why would you expect this phone to perform like an iPhone, Galaxy S6 or LG V10????

And interestingly, this "cheap" phone DOES PERFORM admirably well - not just for a phone at this price point, but also a phone that would cost a bit more.  While it is meant to be a secondary phone for me, I can see myself rely on it more as a primary phone!

Trust me, if you're using this phone to run processor-intensive games, then, of course this is not the phone for you.  Get a Galaxy Note or iPhone 6S plus.  But if you, like me, use a phone to do what has become a set of day-to-day tasks:  make calls and chat on Whatsapp, constantly open more than two email accounts, listen to music on my daily commute and workout, call Uber or Lyft twice or three times a day, read news from a couple of sources that constantly send alerts, and play chess during lunch, this phone is just perfect!

So let me just list the pros and cons which, again for a phone this price, is totally acceptable!!

First, the Cons - just so that they're out of the way:
-  There may be occasional slow down when scrolling up and down a web page when the internet connection is slow, but it's nothing I have not seen even on high end phones.
-  Cellular call sound isn't the best but still doable (in any case I use WhatsApp these days to make calls, and sound quality is much better with this, even on this phone)
-  Battery life, while not terrible, could use improvement.  But this I say about ALL the phones I've had, now and in the past, including Blackberry Priv (which has a horrible battery life by the way) and LG V10 (my "last year" phone that didn't fare as well on the battery department as it's older cousin LG G2).
-  Unremovable battery:  Why??  Especially when it's not a unibody phone, meaning you can open the back door.  Strange how they let you open the back of the phone only for the purpose of inserting or changing SIM cards and Micro SD card.

Pros:
-  Relatively smooth for typical day-to-day tasks
-  Light weight - compared to today's more Phablety standard - and decent design.  My worst nightmare is when I buy a phone from online only to find it looking like an iPhone!  Luckily, it doesn't.  It is more of a generic or non-descript style, but it is still elegant.
-  Camera:  I haven't tested it exhaustively, but under decent light condition (i.e. outdoor or indoor with good amount of light), pictures turn out decent.  Funny how the HDR option has to be selected manually all the time (unless I haven't figured out how to set it automatically), but it does help improve extreme lighting condition like other phones do.  I have seen much better Selfies from other phones, especially Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge and the "camera king" LG V10.  But, again, those phones cost $600+++++.

All in all, this is a great phone indeed!!  I highly recommend it, even as a primary phone.

The only thing noticably different from a premium phone is the camera, which is perfectly acceptable for snaps in good light but won't be confused with an iPhone 6 camera. And really, an iPhone 6 camera is still a long way from a high quality camera anyway.

We'll have to see about durability. Will the buttons and ports hold up? Will the components hold up to day to day banging? But at this price, maybe the thing will be to plan to replace the phone every 12 to 18 months rather than spend $700 and try to nurse a phone through 3 or 4 years because you don't want to pony up for a new one.

Caveat: I may have gotten a slightly defective device.
This device works decently for basic phone functions, under certain circumstances. It can call, text, and surf the web, as long as it is charged, cool, and in solid cell service. It has a decent battery life, so long as you do not let the battery run out. When the battery drops to 0%, one of two things happens. Either the phone restarts, showing anywhere from 25% to 100% battery life, and lasts as long as it normally would on that charge, or the phone gets stuck in an almost endless cycle of powering on and off. I've had to go an entire day (24 hours) without my phone because it shut off due to lack of battery, charged just enough to try and turn itself back on, and then used all of this charge, in the process of turning on, only to die again, before the restart finished. there is no way to escape this cycle, besides leaving the phone on a charger, until it decides to stop turning itself on. Other issues include, not being able to send mms, or access the internet in anything less than optimal cell service (which could somehow be a carrier problem,) Having a very shaky bluetooth connection, that drops and stutters constantly (sometimes at regular intervals,) and a bit of sluggishness (honestly less than I'd expect from a phone of this price.) Otherwise the phone is functional, and the 'leather' flip case that comes with it has saved the screen from a few drops. If the company fixes/replaces my likely defective model, I'll definitely update the star rating.

A great sim phone with a huge potential to be a perfect phone. (just like the MOTO G 3rd) I got the phone this morning but since today is my day off from school and work i had the chance to put some heavy usage on it and would like to provide some feed back for anyone looking at this device.  I got the phone around 10am this morning and upon the first start up i found that it only had 2% battery on the unit.  So the most logical thing would be to plug it into my fast charger (Anker 40w unit with a known good cable) and started installing my apps.  After about 30-45 mins of updating and downloading i found out that the battery level has dropped down to 1%.  Although i would admit that everything was done with the screen on but the battery level should at least move up 4-5 percent over the time it has been plugged in.  Long story short with my inline amp meter i found out that it was only charging at .5-.6 amps (slow charging).  The only way i could get this phone to charge at a normal speed was with its factory charger.  Below are the quick Good Vs. Bad points of this device.

The good:
Quick camera and decent pictures.
Fast and solid gps signal.
Great user interface with a bunch of hidden short cuts to make everything easier.
(smart locks, smart device manager for quick phone unlock, double tap to wake)
great battery life. (GPS, BT and pandora was on for an hour and only consume 15% battery )

The bad:
Super slow charging (.5 amp draw vs 1.0 amp of a normal phone)
Creaky back with the leather case.
Inconsistent "Ok Google"  activation (i use this feature a lot)
Smart gesture only seems to work if the phone unlock.

The pictures i have attached are the different charging amp reading with the Anker 40w charger comparing with the factory charger. (cable is the same)

This means you can't store files larger than 4GB (like HD movies).

I've had the BLU Life One X for a couple of months now, and wanted to give it a review.  I'm not going to go over the specs, as other reviewers have covered those well.

THE GOOD:
* The screen is full HD with great color depth.  You aren't going to find a better screen at this price
* The processor and memory mean that pretty much any app you throw at it will run fine. I've run games, projection apps, and had multiple tabs open, and never had problems
* It will actually use an SD card as your main installation medium.  I put a 32GB card in, so now I have plenty of space for all the apps I could want.  Most android devices I've used complain much more about installing apps to the card.
* Very little bloatware.  They did install the Amazon appstore in addition to the Google Play store, so you can get a ton of paid software for free
*BLU Support:  I had issues with my phone at first (See FIXES below), and called BLU for help.  I got a real person right away.  They gave me instructions on how to potentially fix my phone, and started the return process in case it didn't work.  They then followed up with me a day later to make sure everything worked out.

THE ADEQUATE:
* The camera isn't anything special.  It takes nice enough photos, but doesn't like the dark.
*Reception and sound quality aren't anything to write home about, but are equal to other phones I've had.
THE BAD:
* The digitizer (the part that registers your touch) gets a little oversensitive sometimes and registers swipes a a series of clicks.  It's not enough to ruin the phone experience, but it's what lost the phone the one star that it lost.
* Initially, the phone would reset every time it rang.  BLU Support helped me out with that though.
* If you use Smart Awake, your phone screen may turn on when you're talking on it. Keep the included case closed to stop that from happening.

FIXES:
There are a couple of things that were fixed:
* Battery charge slowness:  Apparently this was software-related, as the OTA update from BLU seems to have completely fixed it.
* Resetting issue.  My phone reset each time it rang.  A factory reset completely fixed it though.

OVERALL:
This is a great phone for the money.  You can buy it with confidence.

Overall I find this to be a quite serviceable generic Android phone. Given that it's unlocked, capable of dual SIM cards, and can take an extra SD chip to increase storage up from a nice 16GB already onboard, this phone will work. There are three separate slots, two for microSIMs and one for MicroSD.

I installed the free app "Z-Device Test" and the specs tested out as advertised (noting that amount of memory is never exact when expressed in Gbytes - e.g., 1.87 GB is rounded up to 2 GB of RAM). Also, this does NOT have NFC capability installed.

Performance in hand was fairly snappy with an AArch64 processor with 8 cores that can run at 1.30 GHz. When I test this just as a wifi Android device I have no issues at all with playing videos, pulling up street view on Google Maps, and taking pictures and videos. Almost all apps I've installed run fine, with one exception: this is not rated for, and does not work with, Google Cardboard. I was actually able to look at some stills in 3D with a Google Cardboard headset, but the Cardboard app itself is incompatible with this phone. That is NOT a deal breaker, but thought I should note it. Two different apps tell me this phone does not have a gyro, even though I know of one reputable site that lists that it does have one.

I actually prefer my Moto-G in my pocket. This phone is more along the size of an Apple 6, actually a bit larger. The screen weighs in at 1776 x 1080 pixels (Z-Device Test) and is visible from all angles.

This comes with a screen protector which I ignored (just don't like them) and a very nice snap in case with window for seeing time and pop up announcements.

Greatest phone ever? Nah. Excellent over all phone for the price? Definitely.

UPDATE 16 DECEMBER 2015 (just later in the day):

Based on questions in the comments, I thought it might be useful to list all of the features the free app Z-Device Test says this phone does and does not have:

Does NOT have . . .

* temperature sensor
* pressure sensor
* relative Humidity
* NFC
* antenna (though you can plug in headphones as an antenna for FM radio)
* gyroscope
* gravity sensor
* linear acceleration
* rotation vector
* infrared
* step detector
* step counter

DOES  have . . .

* main camera
* secondary camera
* GPS
* WiFi
* Bluetooth
* GSM/UMTS
* accelerometers (X-Y-Z axes, medium accuracy, app. 74 Hz sampling rate)
* compass (magnetic X-Y-Z, medium accuracy, app. 15 Hz sampling rate)
* vibrator
* microphone
* USB (micro)
* headphone jack
* light sensor
* proximity sensor
* flash

Also has a notification LED that is capable of two colors, red and green. Works with the free Android app "Light Manager."

I've had this phone for about a month now.  What had kept me away from more modern smart phones was the ridiculous prices associated with most of them, but after some recent trips abroad, I decided it might be time to upgrade and started looking around.  I was looking at the Studio Energy 2 and was close to making a purchase when this little baby rolled out.  I Purchased it for $150 (no, I was not lucky enough to get in on the $100 initial pricing).  I wasn't sure what I'd get for something considered to be a budget phone, but this highly exceeded my expectations.  I would even say they were blown away.  And being someone who take pride in being frugal, I am very pleased with how much value is packed into this phone for $150.  The 5.2" screen is a nice size, not too big, not too small and still fits right in my side pocket of my carpenter jeans without sticking out of the top.  The 1080x1920 makes videos look fantastic, and I haven't noticed it struggling to keep up with anything I do although I don't really do a lot of high demand activities on my phone.  I haven't noticed any call quality issues or terrible battery life.  I looped a video on power saving mode for 3hrs 40mins, and it took the battery from 100% to 73%.  That seems alright to me, but different people may have different expectations.  I get about 3 days out of the battery with moderate daily usage.  Also, the battery didn't get very warm after that long video play back.  I haven't experienced any problems of it having trouble maintaining wifi connections either.  It doesn't have quick charge capabilities.  Not an issue for me as I can just plug it in if it is almost dead when I go to sleep and wake up to a fully charged phone.  It takes just a little under 6 hours to go from 1% to 100% battery.  I'd definitely recommend this phone to anyone who wants a capable, modern smartphone, but doesn't want to break the bank.  I am using this phone with StraightTalk.

great phone for the price paid.

REVIEW UPDATE******************************

I received my replacement phone, and while the battery problem isn't as bad, it is still there.  Where my original phone's battery started "crashing" at about 10% indicated battery life, the replacement starts crashing at about 6% battery life.

This is concerning.  The discharge characteristics of lithium batteries is well understood, so it should be easy to have your phone display a linear % remaining indication.  There are 3 possible reasons this is not happening on the 2 phones I've evaluated:

1) The battery is defective, in which case it could be a safety hazard.

2) The voltage monitor in the phone is not adjusted properly, in which case there could be a potential battery safety issue.

3) The phone firmware could be faulty.  This could be fixed by a firmware upgrade, but if it isn't, there is a potential battery safety issue.

Given that a number of other reviewers have also identified this problem, I expect it's pervasive on this model.  I'd bet that others, if they look for it, will also confirm it as a problem.  It's really sad given that other than this battery issue, it's really a fine phone for the money.

***************************************************
ORIGINAL REVIEW:

I received a defective unit due to battery issues, which I'll describe in a moment.

I had a change to play with the phone some before returning it.  The phone overall appearance is damned good.  As mentioned in other posts, the plastic back looks a bit cheap, but the rest looks great.  The display is lovely for a budget phone...actually even for a mid-upper range phone!  It had a slight color shift which has been described in other posts, but I believe it's correctable.  It's not major issue, however.  I played some video that I loaded, & it played smoothly.  Surfing was a breeze, although I wish it had the 5GHz wireless band covered.  That's one of the cost compromises.

The problem with the battery had to do with end-of-charge life.  Normally a phone should display the % of battery life left as a linear function of time left.  50% means you've got 50% time left, assuming you are doing the same thing in the last 50% that you did in the first 50%.  Likewise, if it shows 10% left, you should have 10% more time remaining.

My copy didn't do that.  I was watching a video as the % dropped linearly with time, until I hit about 10%...then the indicated % fell like a rock.  In no time, the battery went down...9...8...7...6...5...4...3, so I quickly shut it down.  I had broken in the battery properly, so this was not a good sign.  I recharged (& yes, reports of slow charging, even with a 2-amp capable charger are correct) it fully, letting it go 5 hours after it indicated full so it would really be full with a trickle charge.

I then ran the Geekbench 3 battery test.  After running the test, it gave a readout of % vs time, & that test confirmed what I saw.  The % fell like a rock below about 10%.

So the phone is being returned.  Hopefully the replacement won't have this battery issue.

So far, so good! I bought this for my daughter as an alternative to wasting money on an iPod and to get her an entry-level phone. With the native ability to host a 64GB microSD card, this thing can hold a ton of music. Also, to my surprise, this phone has an FM receiver built in that uses the included headphone wires as an antenna to capture over-the-air broadcasts and comes with an FM tuner app that lets you save your favorite FM stations. Initial setup was easy and I'm very impressed with the fact that this is near-stock Android and includes a lot of customization. As one example, you can double-tap the screen to wake the phone, which eliminates the need to press the power button. It does come with some Amazon apps pre-loaded, but I would not call these bloatware in the traditional sense, as you can uninstall them, not just disable them. Aside from the typical included charger, you also get a plastic screen protector and a professional, window-type case that rivals the Samsung S-View cases for their flagship phones. The included case integrates (and replaces) the back of the phone and was of much higher quality than I expected. Thus far, I'm quite pleased and wish now I had ordered a second one when they were on sale at $99. Even at $149, it's a great value.

The Blu Life One X (2016) represents my first purchase of an unlocked cell phone, something that is becoming increasingly common as carriers drop their subsidies on new phones.  The 2016 Blu Life One X is a sub $200 phone that offers decent performance, but one that is marred by a few issues.

Let's start off with the phone itself.  The build quality of this phone is quite good; it feels sturdy in the hand, the buttons are placed in a logical location, and the Gorilla Glass 3 seems to hold up to the everyday rigors of life.  The plastic back detaches fairly easily and exposes the 2 Sims card slots along with the dedicated MicroSD slot.  It's worth noting that the 2nd SIM slot can also accommodate a 2nd MicroSD card.  Specs list these MicroSD slots as being able to accommodate up to a 64 Gig SDXC card, but I have not tested as I only have a 32gig card.  Unfortunately, this also exposes the battery as being integrated into the phone; making a battery swap impossible. (More on this later)

The screen is a gorgeous 1080p with good viewing angles and decent color reproduction, which can be further tweaked in the settings so you can get your color saturation to your liking.  The screen is nearly on par with flagship phones from about 1-2 years ago (The Note 3 for example), not something you would expect on a phone this inexpensive.  While you don't get the 2k or 4k resolution of the current flagship phones, the 1080p resolution is more than enough for it's 5.2" size.

With such a wonderful screen and good build quality, sacrifices needed to be made somewhere.  In the case of the Blu Life One X 2016, that comes in the form of a MediaTek processor and a lesser Mali GPU.  While a majority of phones seem to be powered by Snapdragon processors, Blu makes due with an Octocore MediaTek running at 1.3 Ghz.  Don't let the "octocore" fool you, this phone is not a speed demon.  During testing, several games (Walking War Robots, Star Trek Timelines) dropped enough frames to be noticeable.  Do not expect to be running the newest games smoothly on this phone during it's lifespan.  I am unsure if this performance is related more to the Mali 270 GPU or the MediaTek processor.  Less intensive, 2D games show no problem, so your game of Just 10 Taps or Candy Crush won't be affected.  For everyday performance, this processor/GPU mated with just under 2GB of RAM will serve you just fine.

Out of the box, the phone runs Android 5.1 in just about as close to a stock configuration as possible.  Blu promises an update to Marshmallow; however I would not hold my breath as they have previously broken promises of updates (That being said, they have improved on this.)  Performance is smooth in normal tasks, however the phone can be slowed with excessive use of tabs in Chrome.  Video at 1080p plays beautifully with no stuttering.

With an inexpensive phone, two trade offs are usually made.  The first being the screen (Which is NOT a tradeoff on this phone) and the second being the camera.  I am happy to report that the camera in the Blu Life One X 2016 is NOT a tradeoff.  While you will not get the quality of shots you would with a recent iPhone, the 13MP camera on the Life One X 2016 is no slouch.  The lack of optical image stabilization means you need to be a bit more steady with your hands, but the camera takes good quality shots, even at night.  The shutter response time could be improved, however nothing about the main camera is a deal breaker; in fact the camera is quite impressive for the price point.

The Life One X 2016 isn't without its issues, and depending on your use, these could be a deal breaker.  First, the 2900mah battery takes FOREVER to charge.  I have used multiple chargers, multiple cables, and this phone still charges ludicriously slow.  On average, I am getting about 10% per hour.  I have never seen a phone charge so slowly.  This is problem is compounded by the lack of a removable battery.  I have heard reports from other owners that they are experiencing the same issues, leading me to believe that this is just a trait of the phone and not a bad unit.  For my use case, this is annoying, but not a deal breaker.  The larger issue I have with this phone is this.  The alarm is completely unreliable.  For one week I had no issue with the alarm, however the past few days have nearly made me late for work.  The alarm will engage, but will NOT actually play the alarm sound.  I have turned up the volume in the Clock app, checked the vibrate box, deleted and reset the alarm.  There is no rhyme or reason to it.  Just last night I played for 20 minutes until the alarms worked as it was supposed to.  Satisfied, I went to bed.  Instead of waking me up at 5am as it was supposed to, the alarm again engaged, but played no sounds and it did not vibrate.  This problem has left me flabbergasted.  There is no rhyme or reason to the alarm failure.  After consulting with other Life One X 2016 owners, I am again led to believe that this is not an isolated problem, but another quirk with this phone.  As with the battery issue, my use case does not preclude this from being my main phone, but it may very well preclude it from yours.

If you order options, be sure you ensure that they are for the BLU LIFE ONE 2016. The 2015 is dimensionally different.

I bought this to replace my Alcatel One Touch Fierce that I got for a paltry $40 on clearance at Target one day. My phone before the One Touch was a HTC Droid Incredible II which I absolutely adored (the camera on it was stellar). I hadn't had a reasonably new phone (one that was released within a couple months of me purchasing it) in a long, long time. So I'd been used to outdated and often no-longer-updated apps, operating systems, and the like.

I really, really love my Life One X.

It's snappy and responsive and easy to use. The size was a little cumbersome for me, initially, as both my Incredible II and One Touch Fierce were smaller models and I could easily reach the whole screen with one hand. That's not always possible with the Life One X, but it's a small price to pay.

I do use a lot of apps - including customization apps to make my screen look better (things like Go Launcher, Go Locker, and Zooper widgets), so those kinds of things do eat some some memory, but even so, my apps run quickly and only things like heavier games tend to give me a little lag.

My only major complaint is one that's echoed in other reviews:

The battery life isn't stellar and it takes a long time to recharge.

I use my phone from when I wake up in the morning until I fall asleep at night. I use it to socialize with friends or to play games on. I use it at work, to snap pictures of things, or to utilize things like Google Drive and Trello for tasks and projects. I use it for bus schedules, for grocery lists, for shopping apps, the whole gamut.

When I take my phone off the charger in the morning, I can expect it to drop 1-2% almost immediately. In the time reading things on my way to work I can expect probably another 8-10% drop. If I'm using it a lot at work, I'll usually be down to about 30-40% by the time I leave. That remaining battery life goes fast and if I have to run errands after work and I don't have a portable charger, it'll be bottoming out on the bus ride home for the night.

I've learned to keep a portable USB charger fully charged and handy, as well as an extra USB cable and adapter in my bag just to be safe.

Some people may not used their phone as heavily as I do and they'll probably be more content with the battery life. I may also have higher expectations for how long my battery should last, as well. But be aware that this phone does take a long time to charge and battery life could be better.

My other complaints are minor -

First, I think the camera could be better, but it's still a GREAT camera in comparison to the One Touch Fierce. Bright scenes are often blown out, light-wise, and need to be tweaked with the Professional camera setting (lowering the exposure usually does the trick). But this IS a budget phone and I don't expect iPhone levels of camera quality. I just wish I could find a newer phone with as nice of a camera as my Incredible II had.

Secondly, no matter how many times you select the SD card as the default write disk (where apps and such are downloaded and installed to), it will not do it. Maybe it puts my downloads and photos there? But I am constantly having to go into my settings and into the app settings and moving apps individually to my SD card. It's not the worst thing, but it's mildly annoying because it ALSO has to be done whenever an app updates. For people like myself, who have a more intermediate knowledge of cellphones and write disks and stuff, it's not so bad. But I could see how someone could get confused and frustrated with their phone storage filling up quickly and not understanding why that's happening when they also have a 32gb SD card, as well. If there's a way around this issue, I'm happy to hear it. Maybe I've overlooked a setting or somesuch.

For $150 this phone is a dream. I just bought a second one for my husband, as well.

Edit: After 3 months of light to moderate use the phone no longer works, great for me that I'm 200 miles away from home and have no sound and cannot use the phone to make or receive calls. At least texting still works so I'm not completely in the dark.

After using the phone for a few weeks, I find it to be just ok.
It does have some problems, the touch sensor is not the best and picks up on the smallest of touches causing you to miss-click while trying to scroll, battery life is also not the best I find myself having to charge the phone once per day as opposed to once a week with my nexus under similar usage.

The phone comes with a ton of bloatware, my first suggestion is to reinstall a fresh copy of android.

Overall it's again an ok phone, If you really wanted it I would suggest waiting till the price goes down a bit more as the addition of ads to the installed OS should not warrant the additional $50 price tag that it was raised to from the starting value of $99 on pre sales.

Cons

I will not buy another product from BLU.  I have had a number of issues with this phone, such as the battery draining very quickly when not in use (sometimes by as much as 50% overnight.) I had bought two of these, each is slightly different. One has a creaky backplate, the other does not, even if you swap them.  My power button suddenly popped off when I pressed it one day. I had to contact Blu support as it was just over the 30 day return period from Amazon.  After an hour on the phone, they told me that I must pay to ship it back to them, and that it would take 20+ days before I'd receive my phone back, and that everything on it would be erased.  I will be without a phone for at least two thirds of a month now.  Their service is awful, and while the phone seems nice initially, they are ultimately low quality re-branded phones (that is, Blu does not make or design the phones, they buy them from a Chinese factory and put their name on it. This phone is identical to the Miramax Canvas 5 and the Wiko Fever.)
Blu phones are inexpensive for a reason.

Also, be warned that Blu's software has an audio profile that resets when you reboot. What this means is, if you leave your phone in vibrate mode, and restart it, when you turn your phone back on, your alarm volume is turned all the way down. You have to double check your alarm volume every time you use set the alarm.

I will write my review in the order of my experience, with sectional rating and explanation...

Shipping : 2/5
It took me just over a month to receive the item. I was expecting to wait 2-3 weeks, but I still wanted to receive by the latest possible expected delivery date, I didn't. They screwed up big time here.

Overall physical design: 4.5 / 5
I love how large but still thin, and light this device is, and definitely much better than my galaxy s3.

Speed and Snappiness : 5/5
This is the fastest phone I've ever used, and I see no lag whatsoever, just great.

Screen : 4/5
The screen is gorgeous but there are some issues. Sometimes, the screen touch does not register, and it is unnaturally smooth. I definitely liked the iphone's screen better, and my galaxy s3 felt better although didn't look as good.

Software : 3/5
The launcher and Android 5 is great but it has serious flaws like unresponsive (locked) screen, blind spots (like the upper left "back" button does not work!). Too often, you'd touch screen while talking and mute the conversation, or press the speaker button etc. Some of these are solved by using another launcher, but not all.

Camera: 2/5
This is probably the worst camera I have seen lately. My older phone (Galaxy S3) had a much better camera than this. Also the software is too limited.

Wi-fi : 5/5
I had no problems whatsoever, everything seemed flawless.

Battery : 4.5 / 5
The battery was initially not very good, it went from 100% to 80% in 1 hour, but still gone for the whole day. However, after a few days of use, I installed other, less resource-intensive launchers, and restricted the number of active apps to 2. Now, the same pattern continues, battery drains rather quickly the first hour but drops to 90% instead of 80%, and after a light daily use from 8am to 5pm, it still sits around 70%, which is way better than my galaxy s3 (which is typically at 40% at the same time frame).

At this stage, I cannot recommend this phone for $150 (maybe for $100) but practically all of the issues could be solved with some tweaks, which then would be worth $200 (especially with a much better camera).

its has been only three months since i bought the phone... it took a minor fall last week..no scratches the screen looks perfect but it doesnt want to unlock.... therefore my phone is now useless... the return policy already expired.... i think the policy date expires too quickly... i am very disappointed i will never buy a BLU again

===EDIT - see below for original review===
Thanks to a comment on the original review by 'bob', I have been able to get a custom ringtone to work; however, still not 5 stars because I shouldn't have to use a work-around to get a basic feature such as custom mp3 ringtones to work.

Here's a copy/paste from bob's comment for how to get custom ringtones to work:
Go into Settings --> Sound & notification. There's a menu in the upper right hand corner. Click it and select Add Audio Profile. I named mine My Ringtones. Just give it a name. From this new profile, you can set any ring tone you like.

=== END EDIT ===

I really like this device; however, there is a bug with custom ringtones.  The device will let you select a custom ringtone (provided you have saved the mp3 or ogg file in the correct location), but when a call comes in it just uses the default Blu Ringtone 4 sound. Blu has yet to acknowledge this bug.

Other than the bug, I've had no problems. Battery life is better than the Studio X I was previously using (5-6 hrs screen on time with medium-heavy usage). Call volume is a little on the quiet side, but others have said it is loud enough, so maybe that is just me. The rear speaker is definitely too quiet and low quality.

The best thing about this phone is the display: nice and large, bright even with the brightness slider almost all the way down, and super-clear.

Overall, if it weren't for the custom-ringtone bug - 5 stars. Until that is fixed: 3 stars (-2 since that is such a basic feature and should *just work*).

Summary: A well-equipped smartphone for less than $7 a month service.

We have been using TracFone for our middle schooler - they have a "Bring your own phone" option that cost us $4 for the SIM card and nothing to transfer over from a new or existing account.  For $19.99 we get 3 months of service with 3x60=180 minutes, but more importantly, 180 mb data which is far more than you need for unlimited text messages via Lime or WhatsApp.  We are using the BLU Life One X with the GSM chip which puts us on the AT&T network.

The phone itself is a very powerful smartphone.  The one we were using before (LG Optimus Fuel) had so much lag it was nearly impossible for the kids to play games on.  The Life One X has more than enough power that on games like Subway Surfers or Piano Tiles are fine.  the 1080P screen is as sharp and clear as my Samsung Galaxy S5.  Screen is Gorilla Glass and even came with a screen protector.

I'd say that on the surface the Life One X is as powerful as my 2-year old Galaxy S5.

Although the battery is not removable, there is a MicroSD slot.  There's also a second SIM card so in theory it can be used with 2 services at the same time, if you had 2 different phone numbers you used (for example a business line and a personal line)

The phone is as thin as my Samsung Galaxy S5, but a bit taller due to a thicker bezel on the top and bottom.

I'm pretty amazed that you can get this much power at this price - If I trashed my S5 tomorrow, I'd seriously consider the Life One X over a refurb S5.

Everything on this phone is better than my Samsung galaxy core prime. I had no problem setting it up with metro PCS. I Iove how good the screen looks. Speakers are alright I like the extra sound features for headphones or playing movies etc. It responds amazingly, no lags ever in the last week I've had it. The camera is good in the day time and decent at night. Only bad thing is that something may be messed up with how it charges. It takes more than 5 hrs to charge which shouldn't be the case. I am a big fan of BLU products I have had plenty of different models, now my two favorite models are the Vivo line and of course the Life Series. Now here we have the Life One X. This phone is Amazing! I am all about budget friendly tech and this device oozes it! Now this phone is good enough for a main phone but can be purchased for a back up phone. I bought the white version and I will go over all the pros and cons. Now my cons can easily be over looked for the price but I wouldn't be giving you guys a fair review if I had no cons, now would I ? :)

Pros:
Price (for what you are getting its very very worth the money)
Very snappy phone  Mediatek 6753 1.3GHz Octa-Core processor 2GB ram (speed through apps and loading/ multi tasking)
5.2 inch screen with full hd 420 ppi (now the screen is down right beautiful, sharp picture, saturated color, bright great in sun light!)
4G LTE (now i am in USA with t-mobile so that may be different for your carrier)
Camera is very very Good ( 13 mp rear shooter 5mp selfie, software is smoother and has tons of camera modes)
Dual sim (a standard for Blu phones, honestly every phone should have it)
Running Android Lollipop 5.1 out of the box (very smooth stock android feel)
Comes with case and screen protector (this phone has a flip cover case that attaches to the back of the phone, premium look)
Micro SD up to 64 GB (come with 16GB internal so its not bad for lite downloaders)
HD 1080p video (can shoot great videos in good lighting)
Bluetooth
Wifi
Looks like a iPhone/ Samsung hybrid (giving you the best idea of to me what it looks like)
Light weight (for the size it fits good in your pocket)

Cons:
Battery (now i used this phone for a week straight and the battery dose deplete rather fast, I honesty feel it is because of  management and the screen size. I have bigger phones that last longer.)
Speaker (not the best, kinda small but it is usable, also located on back of phone)
Back of phone (now this only applies to the white version, the back is a textured faux leather material, I would recommend buying the black version because the white got dirty within a week making you want to switch to the flip cover case. The black probably gets less dirty.
Non removable battery (some like this some do not, with the battery being weak it would of been nice)

Overall this phone fantastic specs for the price! Blu really is stepping up their game for the quality of budget smart phones. I really can seem them becoming the leader in that category. For the price you pay you get a great device, that if you were not told is was a $150 phone you would not be able to tell the difference. I highly highly recommend this phone, now also company that with the quick service of amazon and you easily have a certified win!

I bought this device for use with Tracfone prepaid service on AT&T network. All I needed to make it work was a Tracfone LTE GSM SIM and it activated/transfered without issues in a matter of minutes. The APN was auto configured from the get go and the LTE speeds are blazing fast. I get 35mbps+ down and 9mbps up no problem, which is nearly 2x my home broadband speed. I've had over 2 weeks to use the device and have been impressed by it overall. It offers compelling specs and design for the price, and it certainly looks much more expensive than it really is. The curved edge laminated 1080p display is stunning (despite its slight blue tint) and the metal frame coupled with the soft touch backplate looks and feels rather nice. The phone is very snappy/responsive for majority of everyday tasks and the software experience is nice and clean (kudos BLU for near stock experience). That said, it is far from perfect, and it's a folly thinking this is a flagship, or even a high-end, smartphone killer.

Why? Well, for one, while it does excel at the "smart" stuff (e.g. text/apps/browsing/email and other Android features), it is hit or miss at the "phone" stuff. More specifically, the earpiece and loudspeaker are too quiet, the vibration motor is too weak, the proximity sensor is too finicky (screen would sporadically turn back on, with my face pressing random buttons on a call) and the cellular signal is weaker than its peers (e.g. Moto G 2015, or even the cheaper Moto E). The camera is nothing to brag about, even considering the price. It struggles in low light, is slow to focus, and has a slight blue tint to it. With care and deliberation you could get good shots with it, so I'd recommend taking multiple shots for everything. The battery is a mixed bag as well. It does last under load, with well over 5hrs screen on time at 50% brightness, but it drains alarmingly quickly (under 2 days with literally no use) and takes a rather long time to charge (4hrs+) regardless of the charger/cable used. Other niggles are: the power button feels rather flimsy (luckily that's remedied by the double tap screen to sleep/wake feature) and the default sound profiles don't save properly.

Now, I do have a major concern about the overall quality and longevity of this device considering that a stuck pixel developed near the center of the display only yesterday - a mere 2 weeks after purchase. This isn't a deal breaker to me considering it isn't "dead" - just permanently stuck on "green", but it does make me weary of the possible future problems. I guess I'll have to continue using it with my fingers crossed.

PROs:
-Stunning looking display
-Good battery life under load
-Long screen-on time (easily over 5hrs on 50% brightness)
-Near stock Android experience
-Nice hardware design
-Thin and light for its size
-Excellent overall value

CONs:
-Fast battery drain (less than 2 days doing absolutely nothing)
-Long charge times (4hrs+, regardless of the charger/cable used)
-Mediocre camera performance
-Weak loudspeaker, earpiece, and vibrator
-Finicky proximity sensor
-No 5GHz WiFi band support
-flimsy power button
-Display developed a stuck pixel in the first 2 weeks of use

Vs. Moto G 2015 (3rd gen)

-Looks: BLU Life One X (thinner, curved glass, metal frame, bigger/better looking display)
-Build: Moto G (chunkier, but feels more solid, less creaking, partially water proof, better mic/speaker/earpiece)
-Price: BLU Life One X (no contest; you need to pay $220 for the same internals in Moto G)
-Display: BLU Life One X (no contest; Moto G is way too blue and fuzzy, the digitizer is visible close up)
-Camera: Moto G (no contest; clearer, with better color reproduction, better autofocus, better low light performance)
-Battery: Moto G 2015 (no contest; better optimized, two heavy days of work, over a week on standby)
-Overall hardware: BLU Life One X (better display/processors, more RAM/storage, dual SIM)
-Software/features: Tie (both offer near stock experience with little to no bloatware; Moto G is better optimized, BLU has more useful customizations)
-Overall value: BLU Life One X (Moto G may be the "safer" choice, but it's way too underpowered/underspecced for its price)

By far one of the best budget phones I have ever purchased.  I purchased this when it was at $99 last week and could not be happier with a phone at this price point.  Just to give you an idea, I generally use the latest phone that is out.  I have owned, the Nexus 6P, Galaxy S6, Galaxy Note 5, Galaxy Note 4, LG G4, Moto X Pure Edition, and several other high end phones.  Don't take me the wrong way, I am not comparing this phone to them but I just wanted to give an idea of what I usually use on a daily basis.

The software features alone on this phone could be something the big manufactures should look at.  You can actually schedule for the phone to turn off and turn back on for a reboot or just down time.  Also if you schedule your downtime during an alarm cycle the phone will actually power itself on for the alarm to go off and when you dismiss the alarm power itself back off!  That blew me away when this happen to me over the weekend.  You can turn on things like double tap to wake, you can draw a C on the screen to launch the camera app, and draw a O on the screen to launch the flashlight app.  All of this while the screen is off of course but great features.

For everyday use the phone handles everything I need it to do and then some.  I am not a gamer so I do not buy phones for that purpose. I generally use my phone for taking a lot of pictures, surfing the web, posting on forums, and a few other things with social media.  The phone handles the games I have tired on it with no issue.  Watching content on Plex, Netflix, and YouTube look great on the 1080P screen.  Yes I said 1080P screen for $99, that is just crazy.  Most phone in this price range come with washed out low resolution screens that are just horrible in my opinion.

The front and back camera do a good job for what the phone is. I made sure to have HDR on most of the time when taking pictures and they always came out really clear.  Dual SIM works as advertised, I had T-Mobile and Cricket running at the same time and the phone worked flawlessly with both SIMs.

I only had one issue with the phone that was not that big of a deal for me and could probably be fixed with a software update.  For some reason when I have my Samsung Gear S2 connected to the phone and I connect to my car Bluetooth at the same time for media playback.  The Bluetooth on the phone gets a little wonky and disconnects my watch.  This could be an issue with the kernel int he OS and would just take a slight tweak of it to remedy the issue.  I put in a ticket with BLU and hopefully they will address it when they push out 6.0 Marshmallow.

So to wrap up, great phone for the price.  Even at $149 it is a great phone, I have always been interested in BLU as a company and wanted to give them a try.  I don't regret the purchase one bit and have showed plenty of my co-workers and friends the phone to spread the word.

Works great.  Best phone for the money.  I have no issues with it at all.  Battery last me all day and then some even with hard use.  I restart my phone after every charge.  It seems that background apps that run while it charges don't always turn off after you unplug the charger.  I noticed a big difference in battery time when I do this.  When I first got it, I was very concerned about why it was burning through battery so fast.  If you have this issue, try the reboot method after every charge, or check your background running apps. Monitor your "awake time" vs your "screen on time" in the battery settings chart.  They should be similar.  I noticed that my phone was almost always on (even when i wasn't using it)  which is why I was using so much battery.  I haven't identified the actual function or App that is doing this yet.  Hopefully this goes away when they finally release Marshmallow for this phone.

I purchased the White BLU Life One X for $149 a couple of weeks ago but had to return it because of a faulty screen.  I think that the screen wasn't set correctly during manufacturing and still passed quality control (assuming they have that) to eventually get to my doorstep with a defective screen.  When I first turned it on, it worked fine but after 5-10 minutes of having the screen on a white line would appear on top of the screen which would remain on every page or app on the phone (See pictures).  Aside from that defect the phone worked great.

I registered the phone with BLU and sent a warranty service request using their own website.  It's been two weeks and I still haven't heard a word from them.  From other reviews it seems BLU has a non existent customer service department.  Luckily I purchased it through Amazon and was able to return it with no hassles.

Low and behold, when I checked Amazon to return my defective White BLU Life One X they had reduced the price to $99 for one day.  So I bought the Black version and received it within two days with Prime.  This one has had no problems at all.

Both the Black and White BLU Life One X phones were fast with no bloatware.  I haven't had any battery issues with either of them.  They did discharged quickly and took a long time to charge initially but that's expected of many new batteries.  After a couple charges from 15%-10% battery charge they both charged faster and lasted longer.  A full charge on both phones lasted a full day and a half for me.  That, of course depends on how much you use it.  Initially it took about 5 hours to recharge the phone but now it takes about 3 hours to fully charge the battery from 15% charge.  It's no Motorola TurboCharge but it will do.

They both have an annoying issue with WiFi.  My WiFi, for some reason disconnect from the internet when the screen is off.  It doesn't disconnect from the WiFi itself but the internet does not work until I turn the WiFi OFF and ON again.  I checked the advanced WiFi settings and changed it to turn the WiFi off during sleep which helped with the problem.  This happened on both phones.  I don't know if it's Android 5.1 or my old WiFi antenna but it's not that big of a deal since the 4G LTE works great.  I still haven't checked with other WiFi antennas.

If you're considering buying this phone because of the accessories, DON'T.  The case is OK but like others have reported it's a bit cumbersome.  If you don't hold it right it will jump out of your hand.  The earbuds sound like the cheapest, dollar store, Chinese made junk you've ever heard.  As for the screen protector, well it doesn't fit (See Pictures).  It's at least a millimeter short on either side of the screen.  It also covers the flash and part of the sensor.  If you turn the protector the other way it also covers the camera.  I've had several smartphones during the last 10 years and I've never seen a screen protector that doesn't cover the entire screen.  This happened with both the White and Black versions.  Besides, if it has Gorilla Glass then why should it need a cheap screen protector?

I tried the Blu Vivo Air LTE before this phone, however with the Vivo Air missing AT&T band 17 I had difficulty maintaining a signal in my house. At first this phone, the BLU Life One X - 4G LTE was eating up the battery, which was consistent with many of the reviews. However, I discovered that when you swipe down from the top of the screen to reveal the menu where you turn on WIFI and Power Saving, you can also click on the "battery". When you click on the battery it will bring up a battery menu showing the usage, and other related features. If you click on the 3 dots in the upper right of this menu it will allow you to turn on the "battery saver" which changes the upper and lower bars on the screen to orange, and permits the phone to run for a very very long time. I use WIFI periodically, check my mail occasionally, surf the web on 4G LTE and WIFI, use Amazon Underground app, check the weather, text, and place and receive calls. It's now been two days since I charged my phone, and it's at 60 percent battery and telling me I have two days left on battery power. With a few power management tweaks like turning the email syncing off, turning the on screen weather app off, WIFI notifications and a few other features, I can extend the battery runtime for quite a few days. The only feature this phone doesn't have is the ability tho blacklist or block calls or messages built into the Android OS. You can add an app to do it, however; I'd prefer if BLU would add the feature like on the Vivo Air LTE and my wife's phone the BLU Pure XL 4G LTE, perhaps on the update. This phone blows my Samsung Galaxy away, especially for the price, I can get a new BLU phone every couple years if I want to, versus paying too much for the other brands. This phone does everything I want it to and more, and for $130 it's a steal.

This is an iniital review as I just unpacked the phone and it seems to be working ok - however, the case that was shipped with it does not seem to fit. The case seems to be designed for the smaller 5.0 screen, not this phone's 5.2 screen. I have ordered a 5.2 case as I don't want to damage the phone by dropping it when I take it out or return it to my pants pocket.

A very decent affordable smartphone.  Much better than most phones  this price. And it's unlocked so that's great.

It was a bit difficult for me to get into the swing of things.  This was the smartest phone I'd had so far.  Also I had it a month and dropped it a very small distance.... Face down onto concrete.  The screen shattered, of course.  But also chunks of glass and the plastic underneath started chipping off.  It's still usable but highly unpleasant and sometimes I get bits of glass stuck in my thumb. It also seems to run a bit slower too.

 I'm devastated.  I don't seem to have a warranty. No returns or refunds.

I was told I could have the screen replaced at a cell phone repair shop for a reasonable price.  However I do not know if they'll be able to fix the broken plastic beneath the glass.

Also I have yet to find a case for this model other than the one that came in the package.  Which was a pleasant surprise and I enjoy very much.  But I have recently been made aware that this is not very protective of this phone's delicate parts.  If anyone can point me to a super protective case this phone fits in,  I'd really appreciate it.

See Update below.  This was the original problem.

Warning to all:  This phone does not have the functionality to send voice texts such as by saying "OK Google".  I have personally verified this with Blu technical support.  What is crazy, is that the previous generation phone (Life One), which is on my same Cricket account, can send voice text messages.  Another thing to look out for is if using this on an MVNO such as Cricket, you will have to put in an IP address such as 192.168.197.78 in place of the MMS proxy if you want picture messages to send or receive.  Again, the previous generation Life One did not have this problem.  Battery life is the final problem I have seen.  Despite a large battery, it eats through it in no time.  These problems are a shame because the phone otherwise looks great and seems to run great.  I will be sending this phone back to the amazon.  I hope this helps you make your decision on this phone.

UPDATE 4-7-2016:  After many, many hours of online research and messing with the phone, I have been able to get everything to work that I would like for the most part.  Despite BLU telling me the "OK Google" function wouldn't work, it does.  You have to download an app such as "Edit Prefix Number" to add "+1" before your 10 digit phone number for ALL your contacts.  This then allows the "OK Google" function to text or call your contacts.  That is fixed.  As for the MMS (picture messages), I have Cricket, so I put in the following into the APN:
Name:  Internet
APN: ndo
APN:  default, mms, supl
MMSC: [...]
MMS Proxy:  192.168.197.78
MMS port: 80
MCC:  310
MNC:  150
ENSURE YOU ONLY EDIT THE EXISTING OR FIRST APN since adding additional will not work. Notice the IP address for the proxy in place of the proxy.aiowirelss entry.  This seems to work so just go with it.  The battery has seemed to get better by turning off an number of the notifications such as gmail and facebook.  It seems to last through the day now.  There is a new issue with phone calls getting cut off in the middle of the call.  I believe this occurs with use of the "Smart Awake" and or "Smart Gesture" functions under settings. I haven't narrowed it down to one or the other, but with them both off, the calls are not being cut off.  They both have a double click function to lock and unlock the screen.  I believe if you face touches the screen twice in a row close together, it hangs up the phone call.  While the double click to unlock is a nice feature (like what the LG phones have), it is worth it to not have every phone call hang up.  For $100, and with the above issues resolved, this really is a great phone!  I really like the folding cover that comes with the phone.  it had a magnet in it, that lock and unlocks the phone when you open or close it, like an IPad.  Another thing to note, this phone does not have a gyro sensor, so some pedometer apps, among others, will not work.  Not sure why they left out something that costs about 10 cents.  I now recommend this product.
Very good phone for the price

I bought this phone from amazon about 4 months ago and its as great as the day I bought it. I have been a long time user of windows phones, but this phone puts windows phones to shame. Most phones of this caliber would cost about 300 to 400 dollars no contract, but for what I bought it for (150$) it's a steal. The camera is very fast and good quality. Very sleek and thin just about as thin as new iPhones would be and it charges fairly quick for the size and power it consumes. I have never had it freeze on me or power down without reason like my previous windows phones have done. This is an amazing low-cost option for a no-contract phone and I would recommend it to anyone. I will now buy all my phones after this one from Blu.

The only problem I faced was that I got some hairline scratches (probably due to daily use) on the top corner after a few weeks of use.

Due to my shallow pockets, the top corner was often exposed and I probably scratched on something a while back. I struggle to even call this an issue since it was all due to my carelessness and laziness.

I order BLU Life One X during promotional sale for $99 and received my white mobile yesterday after a long wait. This is my first BLU phone and here is my review in detail.
Looks: The white piece looks like a cheap chineese mobile. May be the black one is a better choice. I regret for choosing a white one.
Display: Is superb. Very Bright.
Touch: Is not great. I was using LG mobile which has feather touch sensitivity. So I feel a great difference. That's okay for a budget mobile.
Performance: Is just average and definitely will become slow over a period of time.
Battery: Is taking 4hrs  to charge and will last  more than day on a moderate usage.
Connectivity: I am using AT&T goPhone SIM and is Easy to register on the mobile. Just insert the sim and you are all set. I am getting 3 bars signal in my area. Video streaming is fast over 4G. Call quality is good.
Camera: Picture quality is noisy and video is very shaky. This mobile is not for those who loves to take pictures and videos.
Audio: Speaker is not loud but In ear phone sound is very loud and clear.
Accessories: Cheap ear phones, screen protector and cover case. Better not to use them.
Overall, It is just a budget mobile

I had high hopes for this phone because I owned another BLU phone prior to this one which I liked okay. But after 3 months of using this phone, I can honestly say I would not purchase this or any other BLU phone again.

The one star I gave this phone is for the nice display that it has. But everything else about this phone sux.

Below are details on just a few of the important features and how badly they are dysfunctional.

Camera:
BLU calls this camera a 13mp, but no way is that accurate. My last BLU phone had an 8mp camera and it was much better, and less grainy. Heck, I have taken better quality pix with my Polaroid 3.2mp digi cam 7 years ago. Picture details: after numetous tries and various settings, the picture quality is poor. When taking indoor daytime pix with this phone's camera, the images were very dark, even with a combo of incandescent lighting plus camera flash, plus natural lighting from windows. When I took pix of my crafts for my blog, I tried in a very well-lit place with studio lighting (no flash was used), yet the pictures always looked slightly out of focus, like they have a weird, hazy filter over them. Outdoor pix in natural lighting also appear to have the same hazy filter. Changing the settings within the camera's app did not change the haze nor the clarity. I am not a novice when it comes to knowing how to take high-quality digital pictures, so this result isn't due to user error. The bottom line is, this phone's camera is a very poor quality camera.

Battery:
The phone's battery is extremely SLOW to charge, so much so that it actually discharges even while it is plugged in charging. Just reading a blog post online while it is plugged in will cause the phone to reset if the battery level falls below 15%. Yeah, it's that slow to charge. And no, it isn't because there are too many apps running. I have minimal apps downloaded and I keep them all turned off. The only way to keep the phone from dying while charging it is to put it in airplane mode and not use it at all while it is plugged in for several hours, which is unacceptable battery performance, in my opinion.

OS:
This phone has an updated OS, being the BLU version of Android 5.1 Lollipop. While Lollipop is an improvement over the previous Android OS, BLU's version is very clunky. One major gripe of mine is how BLU disabled the menu button on the home-screen, and instead has assigned that button's function to be Recent Activity. This is a huge problem for me because I can no longer interact with apps in the same way that I could with previous phones. For one example, when using the Facebook app, pressing a phone's menu button on all of my previous Android phones would bring up the option to report an app bug, with a default screenshot of the exact operation that was being reported, plus the option for me to share one additional screenshot for a total of two photos. This is not possible with BLU's version of Lollipop because the menu button is disabled. Now to report a FB app bug, I must go to my Facebook drop-down menu on my profile and click the report option. The default screenshot of the trouble spot is not included in that option. It might not matter to most people to lose the use of the menu button, but for me being a Facebook group owner, this is a big deal. There are a few more issues with this phone's OS besides the disabled menu function. BLU's OS is riddled with random keyboard freezes, as well as random shut-downs even when the battery is fully charged.

In summary, I am very regretful that I chose this phone. I would not recommend it for anyone who needs dependability from their phone or phone's camera.

The bottom line is, it is an unreliable device, not worth the cost of shipping.
